commentBody:
Eau de locker room?

TEAM ODOR
Enjoyed the puzzle!  Was admittedly kind of weird to see the entry for 49D (AMT) next to the clue for 48A (Infinitesimal amount).
An enjoyable puzzle and a solid Tuesday.

Good Tuesday, I enjoyed the theme.  None of the clues were especially tough but I got hung up in a few places cause I knew the answer but had it spelled wrong.  I thought it was Buddy EPSON rather than EBSEN and ATILLA the Hun rather than ATTILA which made the crossing clues tough.
Can someone explain LORES to me please?

I'm trying to decide whether VOODOO MAGIC is unnecessarily redundant.  Any African-based folk religion experts out there want to weigh in?

On another front: Monday, we had a teacher's AIDE.  Tuesday, we have TAS.  Curious.

I tried to do ‚Äúa Lewis‚Äù in guessing the revealer.  Doom circle? Cycle of doom?

Then what do I find? Only my sad little habit that I honed and practiced starting in March 2020. Ha, that should‚Äôve been so obvious. You got me, John Ewbank!
A fine Tuesday with a little pull. Thank you, John Ewbank.

The answer for 45-Across is wrong.

"PLEBS" is neither a Latin plural form nor substantively correct.  The distinction between patricians and plebeians eroded centuries before Julius Caesar's time.

Nothing much to comment on, well executed theme and solid Tuesday puzzle, nothing to put me in a contrary MOOD. I liked BIZARRO and ZOOMDATES, and a fresh take on PGATOUR; getting a little tired of IPODNANOS in whole or in part in these puzzles, can we discontinue them for good?

When I'm teaching med students, I tell them what my former dean always said. Occam's razor says a single diagnosis that explains most of the symptoms is usually right. But then there's Hickam's Dictum:  "the patient can have as many diagnoses as he damn well pleases"! Keep both in mind.

Fun puzzle!

1 down - oof!
Dear John, Re 54 Across - See 1 down.

After putting quite a few miles on my ODOMeter today, I was in just the right MOOD for this.  And when it came to proper names I enjoyed the historical spread from the ancient times (Occam, Attila, ageless Shiva, not to mention plebs), those who might be considered more MOD, Or at least recognizable to baby boomers: Wilma, Ebsen, Richie, perhaps the planet Bizarro; and those currently in the air: BTS, Rita Ora, Rae, et al. A good spread. 

Paradoxically, Occam's Razor (the simplest solution is most often the best solution; the philosophical razor is used to slice away and eliminate less likely solutions) applies less and less frequently the better a puzzle's clues are at misdirection and avoiding hackneyed fill (glue, etc.) and unimaginative cluing. If you asked Occam to solve a first rate crossword puzzle, he'd very likely throw away his razor and buy himself a pack of disposable Bics at the Duane Reade down the street.

A bit chewy for my liking. Though adding in a OomMtd might have been fun. Do not know why I could see Lionel‚Äôs face and not arrive at Ritchie for the answer. Probably last 24 hours before Thanksgiving break brain syndrome

I was Dooked by LORES until I came here. 

Nice puzzle. I guess it was too hard to turn it by 90 degrees for the direction of the scroll. It‚Äôs impressive as it is. 

Thanks

Today I recommended "Crazy Rich Asians" to a friend who has not seen it, and decided it was time for us to watch it again.  Creepy clusters of coincidence these days.  Maybe the universe is running out of stuff and just repeating itself more.

Thanks, John.  Nice puzzle.
RAM is not a computer‚Äôs storage space ‚Ä¶ RAM is memory
More cunning is SLYER, no? Never seen ‚Äúslier‚Äù for this. Thought you were being cute with magyc.

nor'easter nearly capsized me.
that pesky rita ora again, whose name im DOOMed never to recall...
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/11/24/tuesday-november-25-2025/#ny Thanks for the fun, Mr. Ewbank!

Andrzej ‚Äî I wanted to be sure you didn‚Äôt miss this article: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/24/theater/musicals-broadway-theater-hamilton.html?unlocked_article_code=1.308.Vj7B.8RAQIA2wF0gr&smid=url-share It's not exactly "5 Minutes" if you listen to all the suggestions, which I am glad I did. I'm not a huge fan of musicals, though I have seen several shows, with casts ranging from high school students to Austin amateurs to Broadway touring companies. When I first listened to the suggested songs, it was the songs from shows I've seen ‚Äî Porgy and Bess, Hedwig and the Angry Inch, Jesus Christ Superstar ‚Äî that I liked hearing. But Satisfied makes it obvious why Hamilton was such a hit, and as the article promises, A Letter From Harry's Mother had me in tears. I also enjoyed Billy Porter's rendition of Low Down Blues.
I liked the chewiness of this. It was slightly harder than the average Tues but slightly easier than the average Weds. Theme was okay. Nice to see The STOOGES. RAM is not really storage space though.
37 across seems wrong. RAM isn't storage; if anything, it's the opposite of storage. So it definitely wouldn't be described as "storage space".
RAM isn't storage and also The Stooges aren't Iggy Pops backing band, Iggy Pop is a part of the Stooges. Also is Plebs accurate for Caesar? I feel like that's off as well.

I quite liked this, even though in the end I needed to check the puzzle to finish - my fault, really, because even though I could not have known whether some comic planet would be called BIZARRe or BIZARRO, eRS aren't really surgery sites, are they, unlike ORS. I would prefer it if trivia didn't cross with abbreviations, but this was gettable, I just didn't see it. The theme was skillfully implemented, I enjoyed it, and I found the fill perfect for Tuesday - had I not made that error, in would have finished exactly in my average Tuesday time (and faster than yesterday). Lucek the puppy's first snow a few days ago: https://imgur.com/a/jEks39g He looks excited in the picture but generally he was very calm, under the circumstances. Jorge the Lab loved winter, and he went crazy each time he saw snow, rolling around in it and scooping it up with his mouth - even as an old and not very agile dog. When he was younger he would even slide down slopes in the snow, obviously on purpose and for fun. https://imgur.com/iXejvIR
This was pleasantly chewy for a Tuesday. Not so tough that I needed Google help, but challenging enough to make me stop and think. Thanks, John, for this refreshing break from my usual DOOMSCROLLing.

Fun Tuesday grid. I‚Äôve been known to fall down the DOOM SCROLLing hole üò¨ I caught on by the second theme answer and immediately jumped down to the revealer and entered it followed by the remaining shaded squares in the correct order. It definitely helped speed up the solve. NIA Vardalos wrote and starred in My Big Fat Greek Wedding (I and II), My Big Fat Greek Life TV series and also directed I Hate Valentines Day. I think she is super talented. I don‚Äôt even know how many times I‚Äôve seen MBFGW, but it‚Äôs in my top five favorites. It‚Äôs hilarious ü§£
This was my 2100th solve overall (not my streak which is 1601 today). Thanks, John!

Did anyone else find this a weird mix of modern and old trivia? Maybe it was the britishness of it but I felt like the clueing was somehow too old and too young for me at once. E.g. we have cluing for a tiktok star and doomscrolling in the same puzzle as Buddy EBSEN and TOMDOOLEY. I also really dislike 31A and am not a fan of 52A either. Overall just kind of a meh experience.
It‚Äôs almost midnight PDT and I‚Äôm craving a taco pie.Smooth puzzle.

I'm kind of fascinated by the discussion of whether or not RAM (random access memory) is the same thing as computer "storage".

It's hard for me to not consider "memory" a kind of "storage".  Maybe less permanent than other forms of storage, but storage none-the-less.  I mean, on the molecular level a huge number of things (vibrations, collisions) happen over the period of time as short as a fraction of a second.

It reminds me of a great discussion we had here a few months ago about whether or not Adenosine Triphosphate (ATP) was a form of biological energy storage.

I claimed it was, although I learned to my surprise that individual ATP molecules don't last very long, and there were a lot of other molecules (fats, glucose...protein, even) that was a better candidate for energy storage, because it was longer term.

Language is hard.  I think I'm going to stop claiming that I can even speak one of them, as it's so hard to find definitive meanings for words like "storage".
It seems apt that doomscrolling leads to a bad mood.

I love Sam‚Äôs reference to BRIT LIT (which is making its debut, yeah!) and Jane Austen‚Äôs opening line gem, ‚ÄúIt is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife‚Äù.  

So for you, Sam, what do JAMESJOYCE, BILLYJOEL and  ELROYJETSON have in common?

JOY SCROLLING

not me feeling personally attacked by this puzzle just after DOOMSCROLLING for several hours üò≠

thank you for the reminder ü•≤

Nice crossword. 
As someone has said, quite the mix of old and new. I remember reading about BIZARRO world in Superman comics in the early 1960s, and TOM DOOLEY was playing on the radio - such a scary song, and WILMA and co on the TV.

Then completely unknown to me, NIA and RAE (I'm one of the few who has never watched TikTok). I've learnt RITA ORA, GUAC, BTS, YEOH, OTS, MCAT from doing the crossword. 

No complaints here.
What a fun puzzle! The scrolling dooms definitely helped me figure out a couple of entries. (A mid‚Äêpuzzle nap helped me with the last few.)
Ahh, BIZARRO World. https://thenib.com/this-bizarro-world/ Maybe I'll move there.

Jeez, could their possibly be more abbreviations?  Just seems like they couldn‚Äôt create an actual puzzle so they decided to ask you to come up with abbreviations for things that aren‚Äôt abbreviated.  So now you have to figure out how a random person abbreviated pencil.  Seems lazy.

By my lights this was a bit tough for a Tuesday.

I can reliably get ORA if clued as [Rita], but I've never heard of any of her song;. [#2] had me looking for a pencil abbreviation; and I've never been to Tik-Tok.

Came in just a bit above my daily average.
This was fun! The opposite of doomscrolling.

The revealer was a big help today as I figured out the theme immediately, and then promptly promised myself to do less of that!

I went to school with a boy named ATTILA. I don't know what his parents were thinking, but we kids thought he was cool.

i know im 11 months late to the party but apropos of yesterdays references to the ART HEIST and ESCAPE ROOM puzzles ive just gotta say...
i did solve escape room since i encountered it just after i started solving these puzzles and it annoyed me no end.  perhaps now it would delight me...
but i just now finished art heist, which dropped just days before i started...
breathtakingly beautiful puzzle.

From the Interesting Times department:

A 2024 poll concluded that almost a third of Americans doomscroll regularly.

On the other hand, a 2023 study concluded that 39% of people worldwide actively avoid the news.

Probably just me and my brain today, but I thought the theme clue of this puzzle could be: [‚ÄòFor short‚Äô for long] Not a song I love, but always good to hype Metric: https://youtu.be/YjNytMN4QL0?si=1DqTSKnzSyM6UmPD

Props to John for coming up with this theme.  It seems obvious, rearranging the letters of DOOM to get to a DOOMSCROLLS revealer.  But John thought of it first, and, mind you, this catchy verb ‚Äúdoomscroll‚Äù has been in the language for seven years.  Bravo, sir!

Then he expertly formed the grid, coming up with an answer set that fit symmetry, and filled the box with varied and unjunky answers.  Fresh answers too, with 12 entries that have appeared only four times or less in the 80 years of Times puzzles.  

The cluing was terrific, relatively easy but not embarrassingly so, and there were enough footholds to make things accessible to newer solvers.  Making this happen takes talent and grit. 

I loved being misdirected by [#2s in classrooms], where for too long I kept searching my brain for a three-letter answer meaning ‚Äúpencils‚Äù.

I not only enjoyed a fun solve, but the splendid feeling that naturally arises when coursing through quality.  Thank you for this, John!

52A made me angry, because I am a nerd and I couldn't figure it out. Then I crossed it and got angrier, because it still made no sense. Then I added a mental hyphen and peace returned to the cosmos. That's why I love crosswords. Cheers!

This was fun. Again I could not find my typo! Loved the theme-so appropriate for our current times. I try to avoid doomscrolling as much as possible! I‚Äôd rather do crosswords instead. Thanks, John! Y‚Äôall have a wonderful Tuesday!

I got all excited when I saw the clue for 1A. Thought for sure it was going to be DOZIER. Lamont Dozier and the two Hollands were the most prolific songwriting and production team in Motown's history, writing a preponderance of the hits of that era.

When we decided to move to Vegas, we weren't quite ready to commit full time to the move, so we bought a house and decided to rent it for a couple of years. Our R.E. agent got us Lamont Dozier and his third wife, Barbara, as our tenants. They moved a ton of stuff into the place ‚Äîboxes of evening gowns and tuxedos, a grand piano, computers, TVs ‚Äî everything but themselves. They never set foot in the place. The first year they paid the entire years' rent in one payment. The second year we had to run after them for the money. I was hoping I'd get to meet him and maybe even get a signed copy of one of his albums (he performed, too). Alas, it was not to be, and after the second year they left, cleaning out every bit of unused stuff they brought with them. We figured they were using it as an expensive storage facility as a tax shelter to have a Las Vegas address. It was nice that there wasn't any wear and tear on the house, but the downside was that a leak went undetected until we made a rare visit to check up on the house. So my one brush with fame never came to be.
Once again, the 3D printer that creates my stone tablets failed to produce shading, so rather than a delightful Tuesday, for me this puzzle was a delightful Wednesday.

Fun puzzle! I spent a semester in Sevilla but got tripped up by the English spelling of SEVILLE with a second "E." Their oranges really are next-level.

First solve from the northern hemisphere in about a year :)

On the tough side for a Tuesday for me. More than a couple of complete unknowns, so a lot of working the crosses. And.. the reveal was one of the last things I filled in so I was appropriately puzzled until I stopped and reviewed and finally caught on. No big deal. Puzzle find today - a Sunday from September 28, 2014 by Todd Gross with the title "Four by four." Will have to confess that I probably would never have caught on to the theme in this one until I was done. Anyway - some of the theme answers (all straightforwardly clued): SAMETIMENEXTYEAR SALTLAKECITYUTAH WITHARMSWIDEOPEN LESSTALKMOREROCK HOLDYOURHEADHIGH TEARDOWNTHISWALL Seems like it must have quite a challenge to come up with all those theme answers that fit the trick. Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/28/2014&g=16&d=D ....
Definitely a chewier Tuesday than usual; much appreciated!
Please no more Rita Ora!
I feel like doom scrolling is when I go through the comments here on a Thursday with a rebus puzzle I really liked.

It finally happened!!!
A band and the #1 hit song...and I knew both!  Instantly!  
My sister bought their first album ...and in a twinkling we knew all the songs by heart.  

And I loved 1D's clue--the "famously short" REVIEW.
Other than those bits, though, Meh.  (Sorry.  Just no Zing in the other clues, no ZOOM in the solve.  It's not OUR fault that reading the news and Substacks online is DOOM SCROLLing.)
20+ proper names on a Tuesday?   Bizarro!
At 52 across, how does "Like early PC graphics" become "Lores"?

My nit to pick (I called ‚ÄúShenanigans‚Äù) was the computer storage clue

RAM is not storage
Hard drive space is storage.
RAM is active data space which goes byebye if your computer loses power

/exits soapbox

Today's TIL: HMRC, which, for those who don't yet know, stands for His Majesty's Revenue and Customs. Today's nit: Are TikTok stars really "stars"??? Today's bit of nostalgia: I remember learning about Bizarro World from an episode of "Seinfeld": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0LPIc5JIFwk
Trelawney?
If I have time for doom scrolling, the puzzle was too easy ! üòã
cool theme but 25 proper nouns really killed the puzzle...

It took me way too long to figure out 22A, considering that my brother-in-law is a game biologist for the state. If you harvest a deer with an EARTAG, you have to send it to him, along with a form letter, for tracking purposes.
I was convinced ‚Äú#2s‚Äù had something to do with pencils.  Got there in the end tho.

Uh oh, feeling compelled to comment. 

Calling RAM a computer‚Äôs storage space is a bit painful. RAM is extremely short-term memory meant to hang onto things temporarily while you work. Referring to it as storage space just feels wrong. There was plenty of room in those spaces for HDD, SSD, or anything better.
Inspired by 15A, just a small word of caution to women. Talcum powder has a potential link to ovarian cancer.

A Flintstones clue (went off the air in 1966) next to a Beverly Hillbillies clue (went off the air in 1971)?  I reiterate my call to have a Gen-Z staffer review these puzzles!  I am aware both titles got movie remakes in the 90s; that's still 30 years ago (and the BH clue referenced the original series!)

Re: 67A RAE,

I had no idea. But, the crossings were a really fun collection of snippets from my past. Superman comics from 65 years ago, Windows user for the last 40 years, and finally, a Punk reference to a guy one year older than me. 

You only need to know half the answers!

What an enjoyable theme! Found the rolling doom fairly quickly, and filled them all in right away, which made the puzzle easier to do. But not all of the clues were as easy, making it a Tuesday level, rather than a Monday level, but thankfully not a Wednesday level. (Good heavens, she's turned into a calendar!)

After a rough day in the ER yesterday, I am taking today slowly; starting my cooking/baking a day early and resting in between so I don't end up as a patient myself. If you have an Apple Watch you'll understand what I mean when I say: every 50 minutes after the hour, I get up when my watch tells me to, and do another task, then back to do a puzzle or read the news until the next reminder. 

Happy Gobble Week!
While the orange trees in Seville are lovely, ask any Spaniard which city is famous for oranges, and they‚Äôll surely say ‚ÄúValencia‚Äù!
I barely finished this "easy" Tuesday. I have so much new stuff to learn and some to relearn, but "Oh!"s and "Aha!"s kept popping up enough to keep me from giving up for an hour-and-a-half.

There are many dark folk songs like Tom Dooley that are cringy to hear today. Steve Martin wrote a ‚Äústory song‚Äù as he calls it that takes the genre and gives it a hilarious modern twist offered up by Edie Brickell. https://youtu.be/4lFMK3UIa74?si=Z2qGeLdmWJ4y_2Tz
Did anyone else expect the revealer to be CHANGE OF MOOD?

A breezy Tuesday. I admit I‚Äôve had to stop certain channels on YouTube that chronicle what‚Äôs happening in the US. The DOOMSCROLLING was really affecting my mood.

46D or just LIT where I‚Äôm from!
Nice game. Small info, RAM is not a storage space per se. That would be hdd or sdd.

Enjoyable puzzle and I caught on to the trick quickly and on my own‚Ä¶that hasn‚Äôt happened often enough since I‚Äôve dug back in to solving crosswords. I will take this win and head to my music studio for the rest of the day! Happy Thanksgiving week all! Stay safe and healthy
‚ô•Ô∏èü¶ãüçÅü´∂üèª

Coincidentally, NYT games replaced DOOMSCROLLing for me. üòÇ Still a lot of screen time, sure, but I get to exercise my brain, learn new things, and feel a sense of accomplishment. Huge improvement!
I enjoyed this theme, and found myself stumped for an embarrassingly long time before ALP came to me.

While I agree the clueing on RAM could have been more clear, if people do want to get technical then the clue is not entirely inaccurate as some people are suggesting. 

RAM isn‚Äôt an ‚Äúextremely short term memory‚Äù it‚Äôs just volatile memory that‚Äôs cleared when the process ends or you turn off your computer. And it most definitely is a storage device, albeit a temporary one. Your ability to access it directly doesn‚Äôt change that definition.

Hard drives, even SSDs, are slow. If I load up Call of Duty on a Friday night (80+GB game) the game‚Äôs textures, shaders, models, etc get loaded into the RAM when the game loads. That‚Äôs like a holding area for the info so the game can access it quickly. Then as I play the game engine tells the VRAM (graphics card memory) to pull what it needs from the RAM in anticipation of processing (done by the GPU). The general info that loaded at the start to RAM mostly stays there and then loading screens between match add map specific data to it. 

If RAM was extremely short term or not a storage device I wouldn‚Äôt need a minimum of 8GB of it to load/run my game.
Computer storage is ROM. RAM is computer processing.
Being a hermit, I generally DOOMSCROLL on my desktop computer, not my phone. Not really any healthier, I admit.

One more puzzle find. Fairly amazing piece of construction. A Sunday from April 13, 2003 by Charles Deber with the title "What am I?" Three 21 letter theme answers and two 20 letter theme answers. And those were (in order and with their clues): "If I have ___ :" SEVENTYTWODARKSQUARES "... and I am ___ :" TWENTYONEBYTWENTYONE "... and I am ___ :" MODERATELYCHALLENGING "... and I have ___ :" ONEHUNDREDFORTYWORDS "... then I must be ___ :" TODAYSCROSSWORDPUZZLE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/13/2003&g=23&d=A ...

Whoa! One more Charles Deber puzzle. Never seen another one anything like this. A Sunday from January 23, 1994 with the title "Leap Mos." Took me a few minutes to catch on. Here are some theme clues and answers: "REAGAN, TO BUSH" PREJANESSOR "ARMY CRITTERS?" NOVOPUSES "PARTS" OCTARATES "TUNA SALAD STAPLE" JUNONNAISE "QUADRENNIAL EVENT" INSEPURAL "JUST-IN-CASE CRAFT" LIMAROATS "FIX-UPS" REDECATIONS And there were a couple more. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/23/1994 .....

To all the people commenting that ‚ÄúRAM is not storage‚Äù, I‚Äôm just going to drop a couple links: https://www.ibm.com/think/topics/primary-storage https://www.lenovo.com/us/en/glossary/primary-storage-devices Point being: the generic term ‚Äústorage‚Äù is absolutely applicable to RAM, along with other types of memory. The fact that tech folk most commonly use ‚Äústorage‚Äù to refer to less volatile media (such as disks or SSDs) doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs *wrong* to use that term in a clue for RAM. The idea in crossword puzzles is not for every entry to reflect a precise definition or the most idiomatic usage of the terms involved. In fact, clues often deliberately invoke *less* common definitions/usages, which can be confusing (you might even call it puzzling).
RAM is computer memory, not storage.

A short while ago we had a punny-puzzle about Shakespeare, and discussion was made in the wordplay column about puns which worked using Elizabethan pronunciation, but are, for the most part, lost on us.

47D reminds me of my favorite silly Shakespeare pun--in Much Ado about Nothing, Leonato advises Beatrice to be "civil" when speaking to Benedick. She assure her uncle she will--
"I will be as civil as an orange."
If RAM doesn‚Äôt store stuff then what does it do?
How do I get a picture of my dog to replace the circular icon attached to my posts using an iPhone.
1D made my day. Yes!

All this RAMscrolling has made me forget how the whole debate even started. Not sure if the puzzle had a clue for long term memory, but I‚Äôm pretty sure it did,
for short.
For some reason, my time for today is coming up as 988:20:06. I think that's probably not accurate.

All the RAM comments led me (in a roundabout way) to yet one more puzzle find. A Tuesday from January 7, 2003 by Peter Gordon. Five 15 letter theme answers in that one. One at the top: PANAMACANALARAB One at the bottom: BABAWAWASAVATAR And a stack of three across the middle: RAMADACATAMARAN ALABAMAMAHARAJA BANANARAMASAGAS And there were no other debut answers anywhere in the puzzle. Pretty amazing. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/7/2003&g=31&d=A ...

I have frequently thought about 41D as related to our current "post-truth," Orwellian country.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

Sorry, but one more puzzle find. Yet another one with a trick I'd never seen before. A Sunday from June 22, 1997 by Matt Gaffney with the title "Full-Length Features." Three 21 letter and two 20 letter theme answers all just clued as a film in the year of their release: MEETMEINSTPERIODLOUIS HELPEXCLAMATIONPOINT NOBODYAPOSTROPHESFOOL QUOVADISQUESTIONMARK SORRYCOMMAWRONGNUMBER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/22/1997&g=86&d=A .....

For all the pedants who are confusing a crossword PUZZLE for a computer science textbook: Please go to the Wikipedia article posthaste and start editing. The word "storage" is found therein 36 times -- granted, many are in the sidebar with links to various storage technologies, but there are others within the text itself and in the references (you will also need to contact the publishers of these references to have them correct their articles). I also found references to RAM being storage on the web sites of other clearly tech-unsophisticated sources such as INTEL. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random-access_memory
Very cute theme!
Good puzzle, too much trivia.

@Bill in Yokohama

But the theme is DOOM and the combinations that form when you move the last letter to the front repeatedly.  MODO never will occur in that situation.

@Steve L

Cheers, did not realize

@Bill in Yokohama

Just goes to show, the theme is tighter than you thought.

@Steve L

And/or I could read the column before commenting.
@Chris I had the same two errors! Attila was the last thing I fixed.

@Chris

I can almost never spell ATTILA correctly. Luckily, tonight I had enough Down answers to keep me from halving the T‚Äôs and doubling the L‚Äôs.

@Chris

I believe I wrote here once that It's not smart two T's one L of a hun.

@ad absurdum
My mnemonic: Attila's no sweetie-pie; he ain't vanilla.

@Morn

It's LO RES, short for low resolution.

@Morn
Took me a few moments to twig too, but it's not oral histories, it's LO-RES (as in low resolution).
@Steve L Thank you, I came to the comments for this explanation!
@Steve thank you!!!
@Steve L perhaps ‚Äúunnecessarily redundant‚Äù is too

@Steve L

I asked the same question about VOODOO MAGIC in my Fiend review. The dictionaries I checked suggest that that answer is redundant.

@Eric Hougland

Could it be that we sometimes use redundancies to avoid confusion?  

I mean, if a person didn't know what "voodoo" was, the inclusion of "magic" would give defining context.

In James Gleick's book, "The Information", he describes a form of drumming of an earlier society, to communicate over long distances.  Translated into speech, it's incredibly redundant, saying the same things over and over.  

But the point was it had to be, because if it were too short, it would not be easily interpretable.

@Gab

Sure, lots of reccos for your clever observation, but if you‚Äôve ever been on a twin-engine plane, and one of the engines fails, you can bet your buttocks that other engine isn‚Äôt ‚Äúunnecessarily redundant.‚Äù
@Gab Your comment reminds me of a PBS Kids show, Word Girl, with a villain name that never failed to crack us up:‚ÄúLady Redundant Woman.‚Äù
Steve L, We know the def. 3 of your rejoinder; you used def. 1 "unnecessarily" in your original reply. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/redundant
@Barry Ancona You should have been a lawyer. Consider this, then: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/Kp_dCoWumo0?feature=share

Steve,
I edit (documents by) lawyers.

@Steve L
Anyone who thinks there aren't different sorts of MAGIC has plainly never made their own mayonnaise....drizzling olive oil into a blender containing an egg and a little lemon juice just as Julia Child instructs ...well, serious magic!

@Barry Ancona
My condolences.

@Francis
Redundancy in communication is like backstock in retail. You never need it until you need it; until then, it's a waste of time and money.
Then you have a massive system failure and you realize: 'Oh, that's why we used to do that.' 
Current example: just-in-time delivery vs. supply line disruptions. Result: empty shelves.

@Dave

Not really though? Caesar's contemporary Publius Clodius Pulcher (brother of Clodia, whom Sam Lyons discussed here recently as the subject of Catullus's poetry), born a patrician, was infamous for becoming a plebeian and the shenanigans he caused as a tribune of the plebs.

@Dave

Plƒìbs is an uncountable noun denoting a mass of people. Full stop. The only thing the clue gets wrong is when it was in use. Julius Caesar and his contemporaries used an earlier, Classical Latin form plƒìbes (5th declension). Plƒìbs (3rd declension) doesn‚Äôt show up until post-Classical imperial literature, so 100-150 years later. Tacitus uses plƒìbes. 

Was plƒìbs around earlier‚Äîon the street if not in literature? Did Julius Caesar use plƒìbs when rosy from too much wine? It‚Äôs possible; there‚Äôs no way to know. 

Maybe the clue should have referenced Caligula in lieu of Julius Caesar for philological accuracy, but plƒìbs as a collective noun meaning ‚Äòcrowd‚Äô or ‚Äòthe masses‚Äô (the clue did *not* call for a plural, nor did it call for any sociopolitical conclusions) is very much correct.

Experiencing art is one of the greatest joys of my life, but what I like most about it is how it inspires me to think what my emotions really are, rather than forces me to feel specific ones. True art is about the connection between the artist, their work, and me, and how the two people and the creation come together in a unique way. Musicals lack any of that subtlety. Musical theater is to music what a certain gaudily gilt Manhattan condo is to the interiors of Palladio's Villa La Rotonda.

@Sam F

RAM most definitely is short-term storage. It‚Äôs the reason your computer can respond to your requests as quickly as it does. You might say that RAM puts the A in Access.

@Heidi that's not what people refer to as computer storage space. You can take a book off of a bookshelf and move it to another bookshelf - would you describe your hands as short-term storage?  Sure you could argue that your hands "stored" the book for a moment, but no one in their right mind would describe your hands as "storage space"
@Heidi RAM is very specifically not storage, it's memory.
@Mo and what is memory in computer science?

@Heidi This is correct. Surprised people are questioning it. Maybe it's a bit more common to think of RAM as a type of storage in programming? But you absolutely store data (and data structures and objects, depending on the paradigm) in RAM.

@Sam F
Your hand is arguably your most versatile and oft-used external bodily storage device.

@Sam F

‚ÄúRAM isn't storage; if anything, it's the opposite of storage.‚Äù

The *opposite* of storage? I‚Äôm not even sure what that could mean.

Otherwise, of course I get your point‚Ä¶but if someone asked me to summarize RAM as pithily as possible, one of the first responses that would come to mind is ‚Äúephemeral storage‚Äù. This entry was plenty accurate for a crossword puzzle.
@Mo Though their 1st 2 albums were just as the Stooges, from the Raw Power era onward they often went by Iggy & the Stooges. Nothing wrong with this clue.

@CB Iggy & The Stooges is the band name, he's in Iggy & the Stooges, there's a very big specific difference between a solo act with a backing band and a band. The Stooges never backed up Iggy on any of his solo tours.

@Mo RAM is storage. From Merriam-Webster: "a computer memory on which data can be both read and written and on which the location of data does not affect the speed of its retrieval especially : RAM that acts as the main storage available to the user for programs and data" Pretty succinct definition. We think of it as short term memory, which is still storage, but it doesn't have to be, it's just randomly accessed, so quickly retrieved. The more data you have stored in RAM, the faster your processing time. Memory = storage. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ram

@heironymous

It‚Äôs ephemeral storage‚Ä¶but still storage.

If you browse any instruction set (e.g. x86), you‚Äôll see a variety of instructions for ‚Äústoring‚Äù data to memory/registers, along with others for ‚Äúloading‚Äù data from the same. Why? Because RAM and registers are storage media!

Yes, ‚Äústorage‚Äù would usually refer to persistent storage in colloquial tech speak‚Ä¶but that‚Äôs not the right frame of comparison for evaluating the suitability of a crossword entry.

@heironymous

Back when I studied Computer Science (when mainframes roamed the earth), RAM was ‚Äúprimary storage‚Äù and any more permanent storage (paper tape, punched cards, mag tape, or even disks) was ‚Äúsecondary storage.‚Äù

@Anonymous yes, technically it is a form of storage. Similar to how placing something on a shared surface while completing a task is technically storage for that period of time. But can you imagine a crossword clue labeling a table as storage?

@dlr that‚Äôs fascinating. I‚Äôm a current dev, only for the last decade or so. I‚Äôve never had to consider the terminology effect from before long-term storage was a given. Even when it was a 5400RPM 2GB HDD, i feel lucky that it was always just there in my lifetime.

@Ashley

Nothing ‚Äútechnically‚Äù about it ‚Äî computer memory is ephemeral storage.

The fact that ‚Äústorage‚Äù is often used as a shorthand for ‚Äúpersistent storage‚Äù is irrelevant to whether it works as a crossword clue.

And btw, despite its volatility at the level of individuals machines, memory can be (and is) used to implement distributed storage systems in which it serves as the primary medium for persistent data. You might point out that it‚Äôs essential to capture backups of such data in external media‚Ä¶but assuming we‚Äôre talking about valuable business data, this is equally applicable to data that‚Äôs stored on less-volatile storage devices (such as HDD/SSD).

Human life analogy: When you hang your coat up in the closet, are you putting it in storage?

@Riley C

To quote myself from the comment you have replied to:

"In fact, clues often deliberately invoke *less* common definitions/usages, which can be confusing (you might even call it puzzling)."

Tomato/tomato -- you say "clued poorly", I say "clued".

@SBK Your analogy of closets vs. attics actually strikes me as a pretty good one...but I don't see how it supports your point (for one thing, I'd absolutely describe a closet as a "storage space"...and neither a closet nor an attic is an intrinsically permanent/long-lived repository). But all these analogies that people have shared are really just harping on the most common colloquial usage of "storage" among technical folks. I'm certainly not disagreeing with you there -- 95% of the time, I'd use "storage" to mean "a persistent storage layer, backed by one or more non-ephemeral volumes". But that doesn't invalidate the more generic sense of the term! And it's not even some kind of crazy technicality or corner case. Here's a handy guide to the x86 instruction set: https://www.cs.virginia.edu/~evans/cs216/guides/x86.html And, a few select quotations: - In cases where memory transfers are desired, the source memory contents must first be loaded into a register, then can be STORED to the destination memory address. - ...add 10 to the single byte STORED at memory address var - If the 4 bytes STORED at location var are equal to the 4-byte integer constant 10... There are several other such references, many of which refer to registers (which, in your closet/attic analogy, would be more like what you happen to be holding in your hand). It's really not complicated -- RAM is a volatile storage medium. The clue works all day long.
@SBK RAM would be like hanging your coat on the back of the chair you're currently sitting on.

And yet I never quite got the joke until today. So thank you for adding a little more joy to my scroll!

@Agent86 Is the countertop your kitchen storage? Or do you store ingredients in the pantry, shelves or fridge? RAM is more like the countertop to hold the things you currently need. ROM, SSD, or HDD would all be considered computer storage.

@Agent86
This is short of two questions in one:
1. Does RAM store stuff? 
Sort of. RAM is volatile. This means it can only store stuff while the computer is powered. 

RAM can be thought of like working memory. I can hold stuff there as long as I'm actively thinking about it (the computer is turned on). once I stop thinking about it (the computer is turned off) it's gone. 

2. What is RAM for? 

RAM is for holding (storing?) stuff the computer is using now or thinks it will use soon. 

There are four levels of computer memory I'll try to explain with the analogy of cooking Spaghetti Bolognese.

1. Registers/your hands: The stuff actively being worked on. The onion you are currently chopping.
2. Cache/your chopping board: The stuff being worked on immediately next. The celery and carrots that are to be chopped next.
3. Main Memory(RAM)/your fridge and pantry: the stuff being worked on soon or in a different app/window. The can of tomatoes on the shelf, the meat in the freezer etc for this meal but also stuff for your next couple meals. 
4. Storage(SSD and HDD)/your cellar, the grocery store: the stuff being worked on at a later time. Stuff for next month's meals.

Not entirely related but fun. The actual access times are far different. If a register is analogous to in my hand then cache (there are actually 3 levels) L1 right in front me, L2 the other side of room, L3 a block away, RAM other end of town, SSD other side of the country and HDD on Saturn. So don't forget the milk!
